intro: Isocoma pedicellata, commonly known as the desert blueweed, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small daisies. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, displaying a low, sprawling growth habit with silvery-gray foliage. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, producing small blue to violet petals that attract pollinators. Isocoma pedicellata is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient species in desert ecosystems.
